title: Is the 'never give up' attitude always helpful? - Quora

response.answer_text: No, not always. Sometimes giving up is a good thing. The following are a few examples from my own life where giving up proved to be the best choice for me. Careers. Sometimes you find yourself in a job or profession that is meaningless, souless, pointless or otherwise untenable in a major way. In my case, I worked for an intersectional race and gender advocacy NGO with a narcissistic and generally dysfunctional Executive Director. She was unable to effectively manage staff or sustain projects with long term impact. Every one of her former colleagues warned me about her toxicity and her staff turnover rate continues to be atrocious. There were so many red flags. I really should have left before blowing up but my ‘never give up’ attitude kept me in what ultimately was an untenable position. Lesson learned. A bad fit is a bad fit. If you know what you are doing is not for you and you can afford to do so, move on. Find something that is fulfilling and healthy. Relationships. I think plenty of Quorans have written about when to give up on romantic relationships, so I’ll leave that bit alone. But what about friendships? I can think of two very recent circumstances, arguably two sides of the same coin, where giving up on a friendship was the best option. One was a friendship with a fellow parent whose son was friendly with my child. She and I were not super close, but were friendly enough that once she began her divorce I helped her navigate the family court system. After a while, this women began to impose her post-divorce needs (emotional and physical) on me. It got to the point where she would become somewhat offensive if I didn't respond to her texts/calls immediately or give up my previous commitments to be present for her. Finally, I just told her I couldn't give her what she needed and told her that I needed space. She kept asking me stuff, so I very bluntly asked her to leave me alone. That seems to have worked. In hindsight, she generally may not have been able to pick up on social cues and/or might have be on the autism spectrum but at the time I just needed her to to piss off. If I saw her today, I would be much kinder but I stand by my decision. The second was a person with whom I had a rebound romantic relationship, shortly after I left one of the most important relationships of my life. It took me a while but I eventually figured out that I liked the person as a person and he was not capable of being my partner. Because I liked him, I attempted to establish a friendship. I continued reaching out, despite the fact that he clearly was not bothered to reciprocate. After enough rebuffs, I gave up. I am happier for it. I don't care about him anymore, my feelings are no longer hurt. Giving up there made me realize a few things and subsequently makes me better at being genuinely present for the folks that I do love. In sum, a “never give up” attitude can work some of the time, but not all of the time. Ask yourself what you gain and lose by giving up. Is it worth it?

There was a young man in his early twenties who had a dream. He wanted to be an entrepreneur. He decided to turn down a job so that he could pursue his dreams. He spent the next three years trying to get to market but was unsuccessful. Nobody wanted to invest in his product because they did not believe in it; there was no real demand for what he was selling. But he continued to persevere. He borrowed money against his family home. Another two years went by and he lost all the money. His family lost their home and were forced to live in a small rental shed. But he did not give up. He kept trying because he believed in his product. Over the next two years, it cost him his marriage, the custody of his child and he ended up an angry and depressed alcoholic. But he didn’t give up. He got into bed with the loan sharks to push his product to market and yet again, he failed. One day, when the sharks came calling, he had no choice but to jump. Finally, life gave up on his dream.  There was beautiful girl, she was smart, funny, caring and would make heads turn every time she walked into a room. She was madly in love with a boy she knew. He however did not feel the same way. She didn’t give up. She tried multiple times to tell him how she felt, she even destroyed his relationships with other girls. He moved towns to get away from her but she didn’t give up. She followed him to the ends of the earth. She stalked him, harassed him and did everything she could to try and win a place in his heart and life. Eventually they both got married to different people but she still didn’t give up. She tried to destroy his marriage and win him back. She caused him pain and suffering through it all and completely neglected her own marriage in the process, which eventually failed. She started heavily drinking, became an abusive mother and ruined her kid’s childhood. But she didn’t give up.  Today, we have been tuned to buy in to the “never give up” attitude. We are repeatedly told the success stories that came off the hard work, dedication and perseverance of those individuals that made it. What we fail to realize is the heavy selection bias in these stories. What nobody tells us is about the tens of thousands of lives that were destroyed because people kept swimming towards an unreachable island. We need to realize and acknowledge that failure is not a sign of weakness. It is a learning process. Amazon and Microsoft tried to enter the smart phone business but gave up after only one iteration. It was a very wise business decision. They learned from their mistakes and moved on. Had they kept up the “never give up” motto, they would suffer heavy losses along the way. I’ve come to learn that any extreme is always detrimental. Only a Sith deals in absolutes. You need to find the right balance. Do not be afraid to give up. There are great lessons to be learned in that too. Be adaptable, be flexible, be willing to pivot. Bend with the wind and you’ll never be broken. Some things in life are worth moving heaven and earth for. Similarly, some things in life are not worth pursuing down an endless rabbit hole, the depths of which you might never return from. Choose your battles wisely. Not every fight is worth fighting.  I’d like to leave you with some lines from one of my most favorite songs: You've got to know when to hold 'emKnow when to fold 'emKnow when to walk awayAnd know when to run -Kenny Rogers (The Gambler)  In keeping up with my recent endeavors to try and make Quora a little more interactive and not just one-sided, do share your “never give up” stories in the comments or via DM. What lessons did you learn by giving up or not giving up on something?  In case we haven’t met before, I’m Rohan Kamath.Thank you for reading. I hope I could help you ponder today. :)

If you want practical advice, then my answer is “NO”. The “Never Give up” attitude isn’t helpful always. Of course, you need an explanation for my vague statement. I will try to keep this answer precise and as short as possible. Let’s deduce the above statement with an example:- There is a wall which is built with Ambuja cement. Now, there is an “Ant”, which wants to go beyond this wall. It has two options:- Take a long route and cross it.Or, break this wall and then cross it.People around ant motivated it, and suddenly ant started believing that it can break that wall. What do you think, what will happen? Sometimes, you need to understand your limit. People around you will keep motivating you to achieve your goal, and in this process people forget what they are actually capable of. Like the ant, which was capable of crossing that wall after taking long route, but it forgot its capacity and started believing in something which wasn’t possible at all. Your attitude matters, but it should be in the right direction. People remember successful persons where, Their struggles become motivation.Their Story becomes inspiration.But, at the same time you should also consider that behind every successful person, there are millions of failed people; if they would have tried in different field of their interest or capability, maybe there could have been a chance of them becoming successful. Remember, every person on this planet knows their capability. If you know you can do this, then go for it. Never live in a fairy tale. If you don’t have acting skills then you can’t become Tom Cruise, but if you can sing then you should try to become a singer. Don’t waste your effort in becoming something, which you never were. It will only waste your time and energy. Because, every failure exhausts you and again you need to start from zero. Effort and courage are not enough without purpose and direction. — John F. Kennedy To become successful sometimes, You must either modify your dreams Or, Magnify your skills. — Jim Rohn PS: Those who misunderstood the message of this answer, I want you to explain that I am not defending that giving up is good. I want to convey that “Never Give Up” is not “always” helpful.

I am a firm believer in the power of persistence. Persistence, if done correctly, could lead you to your desired end result. Most successful people will tell you that up front. Persistence will allow you to go through the challenges and failures and learning to achieve the success you desire. However, the “never give up” attitude is incredibly misunderstood. The term does not mean to stay stubborn and stick to the same strategy that may not be working. That is called being arrogant and unaware. In life, it is all about trying, doing and pivoting. We make an attempt to see what sticks and what does not. If we progress, then we are on to something. If not, then this is when we forge another path, also known as pivoting. My favorite story is Justin’s squeezable nut butter packets where the company was failing to sell in stores. He tried everything to get it to sell well, but nothing was working except for this last tweak. He convinced Whole Foods to move the squeeze packs from the energy bar section (originally thinking that people would want squeezable peanut butter as a form of energy while doing physical activity) to the peanut butter section, which instantly turned around the fortunes for the company. There are so many ways in doing something to get to the end result. Some strategies are better than others, but being aware in making a change is key. We do not like to talk about it, but luck does come in to play in many situations. This is not talked about much, because we want to believe that our hard work could lead to success. Not all products will sell well, not all business ideas are ideas that would be great for people and other businesses. We could be the greatest salesmen and saleswomen on earth, but who decides what is great and what is not? The market does. If people do not want the product at the end of the day, then nothing happens. What producers could do, is making an attempt to find, or develop a product/service that that they do want. The only way to find it is to try. Persistence is admirable. It is continuing to find something that does work.

Whether you are called “determined” or “stubborn”… whether you are encouraged to “keep going” or “give up”… depends entirely on whether the person agrees with you. GALLIPOLI (stubborn)  When Churchill was Secretary of the Navy during WW1 he advocated for attacking the Turkish city of Gallipoli (no relation to me, your humble writer Anthony Galli). His 2nd in command resigned in protest, “You are bent on forcing [Gallipoli] and nothing will turn you from it — nothing. I know you so well!” Churchill indeed forced the issue and the English attacked. It was a disaster. One of the worst in military history. 120,000 young men died largely because of the decision of one man! Churchill’s wife, Clemente would later say, “I thought he would die from grief.” “If you’re going through hell, keep going.” — Winston Churchill NAZISM (determined)  Churchill’s stubbornness came out again in the lead-up to WW2 where everyone virtually disagreed with him, but yet he stood firm. Churchill stubbornly believed that Hitler was bent on war and was not a man who could be reasoned with. Churchill ended up being right, and because he was one of the few men who had sounded the alarm, he was asked to become Prime Minister to lead the nation through uncertain times. “We shall go on to the end. We shall fight in France, we shall fight on the seas and oceans, we shall fight with growing confidence and growing strength in the air, we shall defend our island, whatever the cost may be. We shall fight on the beaches, we shall fight on the landing grounds, we shall fight in the fields and in the streets, we shall fight in the hills; we shall never surrender.” —Winston Churchill  All great leaders are stubborn/determined. And this was never more true than for Winston Churchill… “Never, never, never give up.” — Winston Churchill One of the things that makes a person “great” is their willful irrationality or delusional optimism. Churchill would fight through at any cost [watch my essay on Abraham Lincoln], while a rational person would have given up long ago. “For myself I am an optimist — it does not seem to be much use being anything else.” — Winston Churchill Churchill would sacrifice his health, happiness, fortune, and reputation in the interest of seeing the Allies through WW2. This is the true mark of greatness. We grow in proportion to our cause. The hard part is choosing when to be stubborn and when to be flexible. This requires wisdom because it depends on the situation (there is no simple formula). But overall I would say if you want to be happy be flexible on the small things and if you want to be great be stubborn on the big things. But again it requires wisdom to know when something is “small” and something is “big”, which can be especially difficult to decipher when we are caught up in the whirlwind of emotion. In the movie “The Darkest Hour” there is a historically accurate scene where Churchill shouted at his secretary over a mistake she made when she accidentally started typing in single-spaced lines instead of double-spaced lines.  Should Churchill have been more flexible with his secretary? I think we would all agree he should have been more compassionate, but his stubbornness might not have been misplaced because successful people are often regimented. This is one of the reasons why a lot of famous people get a reputation for being divas. They need things just right and any deviation can throw them off. But I think part of what makes these divas so successful is their attention to detail in their craft. As the piano was to Bach, and the canvass was to Picasso, the typewriter was to Churchill. The greats have a higher standard. “I am easily satisfied with the very best.” — Winston Churchill This is the tradeoff of being great: they are more likely to be stubborn when they are right, but also when they’re wrong, and they are more likely to be stubborn on big things, but also on small things. “Never give in, never give in, never, never, never, never — in nothing, great or small, large or petty — never give in except to convictions of honor and good sense.” —Winston Churchill We would be wise to empathize with this when we read biographies and watch biopics because sometimes to demand the absence of weakness would mean cutting off the strength. And as much as we talk down “stubbornness” we are actually quite attracted to it. At first people say, “Stop, get real, quit dreaming, be practical”, but the longer one sticks with it, eventually people start to come around and think, “Wow, he is still at this thing/cause/idea/business. If it is this important to him then maybe he’ll succeed?” They develop respect because they see how much it matters to you, and in a world that constantly feels like nothing matters, people gravitate toward people who live with a sense of “matter” because they want that same feeling for themselves. Maybe not for the same thing, but for something. “Success consists of going from failure to failure without loss of enthusiasm.” — Winston Churchill Stubbornness will at first make you unpopular, but as was the case with Churchill, he was willing to be disliked in the short-term so that he could be loved in the long-term. “You have enemies? Good. That means you’ve stood up for something, sometime in your life.” — Winston Churchill He was willing to say what he thought was right, even when everyone thought he was wrong, because to be great means fighting on, against all odds, to ultimate victory.

Yes , of course , it is helpful. Never give up attitude is very helpful in becoming successful in life. But it is very hard to develop a such kind of attitude. You may think that from now you will never scare from failures or you will always face the problem with a determined mind. But my friend believe that it will be for only the time being. Most of the people will give their good practices after few days. It is in the human nature that people are more likely to develop a bad habit than a good habit. So the problem arises here how one can keep never give up attitude alive in themselves forever. We all that we always care for our future. But we hardly do things for making it brighter and brighter. It very easy to develop a thought of give up atitude. But as I have said earlier it is hard to develop a habit of that. But for developing a such kind of attitude in yourself, first of all you must start thinking that you can do anything from everything. And no one can stop you from being what you want. You will never lose the hope no matter what has happened . You will always face the problem with a bold and strong mind. You will never care of others. Whenever you will feel that now you can't do things just start asking from yourself why you can not do things. Trust me you will never get an appropriate answer and no one can be fool himself or herself. One can never tell lie from oneself. You will find that you can do it the things but at the cost of something that you are not willing to afford . I can afford that but the matter of the fact is that you are not willing to do it. And remember one thing you must always be motivated from yourself. Once you started thinking that trust my friend you will never fail in your life and success will at your feet.

Being part of the human race you are the one of the most resilient and strongest beings to have ever walked on the earth. You are practically legendary. Comparing you to people who lived just 100 years ago you will notice that you know a lot more things than they did and you are 1000 times more connected and up to date then they could even imagine. There are a countless number of positives inside of you that you probably don’t even realize. And every now and then when you lose motivation a quick reminder of what your potential is can really help. Just always keep in mind that to taste success you are always faced with temporary defeat. If you give up at these defeats you will fail, but if you keep going you will become successful. These strategies will inspire and motivate you to keep going. 17 Reasons To Never Give Up: 1. You Are Alive And You Can As long as you are alive you have no excuse to say you can’t. If you put your mind to it, you can do anything. Anything is possible. So many of our dreams at first seem impossible, then they seem improbable, and then, when we summon the will, they soon become inevitable. – Christopher Reeve The only valid excuse to give up is that you are dead, and if you’re reading this well_ 2. Believe In Your Dreams When you give up, you give up on yourself. Don’t sell yourself short and don’t let anybody bring you down. If you can dream it you can do it. There have been millions of dreamers before you and if they had given up the world wouldn’t have been the same. Take the example of the Wright brothers who faced sever ridicule when they tried to make flight a reality. Everybody laughed at them and told them it was impossible. They proved the world wrong, and now flight now is considered a common means of travel and it has changed the world. Hold fast to your dreams, for without them life is a broken winged bird that cannot fly. -Langston Hughes 3. You Have Everything You Need Everything you need to reach your goal is already inside of you. Don’t make excuses, if people can play sports at the Olympic level with disabilities; your short-comings begin to look irrelevant. Be thankful. And use your God given blessings.  4. You Don’t Want To Regret This Regret is the worse feeling a person can feel. Don’t put yourself in that position and do what you have to do, now. I do not regret the things I’ve done, but those I did not do.- Rory Cochrane 5. You Need To Prove It To Yourself You want to prove it to yourself and the world that you can. Don’t let anything stop you from your goal.True failure isn’t when you miss the mark; but it’s when you give up. You are more capable and quitting is for losers. 6. Success Feels Great There is no better feeling in this world other than knowing that you faced an obstacle and that only through grit and determination you overcame it and became successful. 7. It Could Change For The Better It might be really tough now, but it can all instantly change. If you keep going at it you never know when you’ll hit a breakthrough. Don’t be like the person who dug a well 50mand gave up justifying that he was digging a dry well. And the person who came after him dug 1 m and hit water. 8. This Is Meant To Happen You were destined to do this. Nothing can stop you but yourself so keep going at it and never give up. #BecomeLegendary  9. You Are Strong You have the strength to do whatever you want and no matter the amount of setbacks you face you have the strength to keep going. 10. Pride You have high standards for yourself and you must try to never fall short. Work as hard as you have to, for as long as you have to, to achieve your goal. 11. Learning You will learn a lot from not giving up. You will learn about your strengths and your weaknesses. How to do things better next time and most importantly you will learn how to tackle the problems that you face head-on. 12. It Could Be Worse The situation could be a lot worse and you should be thankful for being able to face what you are facing, because there are people out there who have much bigger problems. 13. You Deserve Happiness And Success Everyone deserves happiness and success, including you. Don’t let these small bumps in the road take away your right. 14. Inspire Others Be an inspiration for others. Refuse to give up and try your hardest; you never know who is watching. Your hard work and dedication could be the spark that was needed to light the dreams of those around you. Maybe you have children or siblings that look up to you. You are a hero. 15. Failure Is Normal It’s impossible to reach success without first facing failure, so don’t let anything stop you. Failure is a normal process in life. It’s not the end but just a stream changing directions before it finally reaches the ocean. I can accept failure, everyone fails at something. But I can’t accept not trying. -Michael Jordan 16. Things Can Only Get Better By sticking to your goal and being persistent things can only get better. If you’ve hit rock bottom or feel you’re on your way down. Remind yourself that with the right amount of hard work what comes down must go up. Hard work and determination can get you anything in life.  17. It’s Always The Darkest Before Dawn Understand that the hardest trials are the ones that come right before the breakthrough. So stay persistent because at any given moment you are at the tipping point and success awaits you. Commitment leads to action. Action brings your dream closer. – Marcia Wieder Best of Luck! :)

Yes For me Never give up attitude is always helpful . There are 10 things that will happen when you adopt the never give up attitude. 1. Elimination of fear Defining moments like a graduation, job, marriage, house, relationships, failures, and pain are daunting moments. Our conscious mind dwells on living up to expectations that society pushes on us. A never give up attitude can be used to quash doubts that you once had and become more confrontational with your fears as opposed to backing off. The attitude itself helps you initiate the battle that you’ve been wanting to win all your life. “Just a tiny drop of doubt can poison an entire well of faith.” 2. Doors of creativity and an unlimited feeling We live in a society that has deep-rooted in us with a timeline that things have to be done this way or must be achieved by this age. The problem with this way of thinking is that it creates a mindset of scarcity instead of abundance; “why isn’t anything happening.” A never give up attitude pushes us beyond our limits to explore different methods thus opening the doors of creativity. Creativity is like when you open the windows and the fresh breeze of air hits you. This helps you see life in a fresh new perspective, therefore the mind becomes focused on the unlimited rather than the limited. Many great minds try things that are not of the norm, which gave them this endless feeling. 3. Burning desire stays lit “Desire is the starting point of all achievement, not a hope, not a wish, but a keen pulsating desire, which transcends everything.” famously said by Napoleon Hill. A highlight of the current generation is that there is a lack of motivation. However, with the right push and the right mentality the burning desire can stay lit constantly. The words I always hear are “I don’t feel motivated” – the truth is if you want it bad enough you would stop at nothing. The message here is keep moving and stay busy, any little thing you do can amount to something big at the end of your journey. 4. Going where many don’t dare to go A never give up attitude has taught me to work hard on all levels; physical health, well-being, work, sports and hobbies. This in turn gave me a greater output of results. Whenever I say “I will never give up”, I dare myself to take risks that nobody else dares to and within that process you can reap massive rewards. Whilst others are laid back and choose to do nothing, there you are with your spirited and hungry attitude to pounce on every opportunity. 5. You become the lion with a relentless work ethic Think about what sets apart the top dogs within their specialties from the rest. It is in fact a mere willingness to do anything for success. Are you that type, the one that will stand their ground, ready to fight for your dream or are you the sheep just like everyone else? Never giving up allows you to develop and think of new strategies because there is always a way. Whether you must stay up all night, stay late at work, or miss your friends party, this is what the serious ones will do. 6. Improve the world When you achieve whatever you set out to achieve, you can use your success to make a difference to the world or other people’s lives. Slowly as you achieve your goals there is the feeling of wanting more. You transfer your mindset and life skills to people who are far worse than you. Inside, you feel complete and you want to pass the never give up mentality to those who are going through what you have already embarked on your journey. Purpose and your big “why I am here” are answered. 7. Believe that anything is possible When you refuse to give up you are more likely to source energy to jump that hurdle that you’ve been meaning to overcome. The measure of success comes downs to winning the battle between the perception of that it is impossible to achieve and the willingness to get out of your comfort zone. The only way is to never give up. Ask yourself what if I kept going rather than just give up… can the outcome be different? 8. Emotional intelligence The capacity to be aware of, control, and express one’s emotions is key to handling if things don’t work out. Just because you never give up does not mean you will achieve 100% all the time. Right now, there are many people who are in a worse situation and environment than you are right now. It is ok to lose sometimes. You can’t win all the time but at least you can control the damage and embrace that learning is all part of the process. 9. Not quitting becomes the only option My teacher always used to say to us as students “prepare for failure”. He said in life you must always be ready and be prepared for anything. If you remain in a state of always being alert to danger, chances are you will avoid making mistakes. The more you stay hungry or have this feeling that you have something to lose, the harder you fight for your dreams. On the contrary, if you give up at the first sign of struggle, then you are not ready to be successful. 10. You grow stronger I must do this for me and keep going to become better as a whole. In doing so, you learn so much about yourself by evoking personal reflection. When the physical state and mental state are pushed in positive ways they become synchronized like a harmonious melody. Following this, the gates of the soul open to true growth and freedom. Even when the body has suffered, the blood, sweat and tears have worn you down, the mind still lives and that never dies. Therein is the epitome of the human mind; a mind so great and mysterious that it is able to achieve anything. It can endure unknown situations which give you that drowning and suffocating feeling. Whether you’re reading this at 2am in the morning or in the evening, the never give up mentality is being awakened, telling you to carry on. The complexity of life both the economic and social hardships in which we currently live in makes it easy to get carried away by the feeling of defeat. Like they say, you can get back up so never ever succumb to defeat because in this world you are not allowed to give up. Take a deep breath and don’t you dare give up.

We, humans, are aggressive rather defensive beings, well most of us are aggressive. But we fail to show the same attitude when it comes to “proving ourselves”. We, sometimes let things go away easily. So, if one possesses a “never give up” attitude, it's always helpful as it will help him achieve his/her goal. But wait, here’s the catch, with the “never give up” attitude comes stress, anxiety, depression and a lot of “Why am I not able to do this?” questions. To make you understand, let me take a simple example, Let’s assume you are given a task which you have to complete in 3 days, and the task is totally new to you, i.e. you have no idea of pre-requisites for the task. On day 0, you find out that the task requirements are too high and you don’t possess the skills required for the completion of the task. Now you have two options; Quit and say the task a “Goodbye”Take up the challenge and complete it (never give up attitude)You chose the second option, now you have 2 days and you have a lot to learn to complete the task. You try to learn everything overnight and plan your schedule to complete the task by day 3. It’s hectic and you’re losing time. This leads you to mental exhaustion. You still try to continue with your task, the second day, until and unless you see a ray of hope you feel dejected and pessimism occupies your brain. This is when the person undergoes various different phases such as depression, a feeling of “good for nothing” and what not. But, because of your “Never give up” attitude you never try to find an excuse to leave the task, you rather try to fight and continue the task and complete it. And on day 3 you see a beautiful result, you had an option to quit and fall asleep without any mental pressure, but you chose not to give up, you were spending sleepless nights just to achieve something. That is the taste of “Success”, when you earn things by mere hardwork!  Image Source: Pexels

An atrocious moment of 1985 at Apple Office. Steve jobs had been withdrawn from Macintosh team. Apples former CEO John Sculley convinced Apple Board of Directors to eliminate Steve’s responsibilities as team leader of Macintosh product team and managerial power for the betterment of Apple corporation at long term. Earlier Jobs had lots of argument and clashes with John Sculley with different decisions. Steve tried to influence the Apple by his own leadership as he had visionary ideas. Steve wanted to reduce the price of Macintosh computer but Sculley did not agree with it while he thought that it will not increase profit. Steve founded apple at 1976 with his friend Steve Wozniak. Apple Board of directors thought that Steve is too young to perform as CEO. So, Steve favored John Sculley to perform as CEO who was the successful, youngest ever CEO and president Pepsi at that time. After forcefully withdrawing from Macintosh computer division, Steve had given new office and responsibilities in Apple. But Steve felt depressed and insulted. So, he took a break. He traveled Soviet Union and Europe. At December, 1985, Steve left Apple. Steve had “never give up” attitude when fighting with John Sculley with several decisions because Steve founded Apple with long vision to change the technology world which was not matched with john Sculley’s Principles and decision making. Certainly, the battle between Steve and John made the situation more weird and difficult. Literally “never give up” attitude is not always helpful. Sometimes, people forget to consider the reality. Finally, Steve resigned Apple despite the co-founder of Apple. In fact, he gave up all the ambitions and dreams which was encircled with Apple. At 1986, Steve started his new company “Next” which is an amazing software and computer Company. He worked insanely with his personal projects. Basically at this phrase of time, he entered most creative stage of his life where he did not have any expectations and responsibilities like past, he was free to do any work. Steve purchased Pixar movies at 1986. Pixar made top class blockbuster animation movies under the visionary leadership of Steve Jobs. 1986–1995, Steve made amazing change in his lifestyle, personality and work style. Interestingly 1996, Next had been acquired by Apple computer. Steve had been offered to maintain as CEO by Board of Directors and he become CEO of Apple again. Steve made tremendous change in his mindset and team methods. He was completely a new person after coming back to his own company. His creativity continuously evolved at new innovations and creativity. Then, launching Apple touch phone broke all the business record in smart phone market at 2007. Now The i-phone is highly successful and prestigious brand in the whole world. There are lots of inherent learning from this incident. Winning life at long run, we have to give up attitude for our own benefit. Certainly, life is not smooth all the time, we have to compromise with the situation instead of adamant attitude. The situation demands that behavior. Sometimes leaving expectations and giving up everything help to rediscover our potentiality and enhance inner strength which completely change ourselves. Steve did the right thing to give up everything. That sacrifices changed him as a person and made him legend. You want my honest opinion? Well here it goes… In my point of view, no, it is not helpful. It may boost confidence for less than a minute and make you feel good for a short period of time, but really, did it help? Sometimes you need to ask yourself questions like that. Is this helping my attitude? Does this make the situation better or worse? Is encouragement always encouraging? I've always absolutely hated when people say things like… “It's all going to be okay.” ”Don't give up!” OR “It gets better.” Because truthfully? Not everything will get better, giving up is so much easier than fighting for something that is worth nothing, and it will probably not be okay! At least for a little bit depending on the situation. This attitude can also backfire very easily. Believe me. If you are upset you probably don't want people saying: “Hey, don't give up.” Because usually they have no idea what's happening or they haven't been through what you're going through. It might even make you feel worse. Imagine you are 11 years old or so. You are at school, eating lunch all by yourself, you are obviously sad. Someone comes and sits with you which makes you happy until those ugly, fake, words come out of their mouth.. “Don't worry, whatever is wrong, it will be okay. Don't give up. It will get better.” Then they leave you. How would that make you feel at your age now if something similar happened to you and how would it make you feel at a young age? So tell me, do you think that the “Don't give up!” attitude is always helpful anymore? I don't believe so.

Let me tell you an interesting story first before directly jumping into a conclusion. One fine day, I was reading a book with full of concentration and one mosquito perfectly managed to break the rhythm. He started hovering around my book and then sat on the pillow and I started observing him keenly. He started stinging on the pillow, as it was soft he managed to prick but did not get blood out of it. “Attempt Failed.” I got more curious and started watching him carefully. After that, He “gave up on the pillow” and sat on the floor. Started stinging again, but the surface was more hard than the previous one and could not even able to prick in it. “Second attempt Failed.” Now it was a lottery time for him. He came and sat on my hand, bitten me and suck the blood out of it. “Mission Accomplished” End of the story !!! Now, you might be thinking what’s the relation between the answer and this story ? (You may have noticed the same story in your life many times, right?) But, The key point here is the “GOAL”. For a mosquito, His goal was to suck the blood and satisfy his hunger. He changed many paths, got failures but did not change his goal. Yes, “Never give up” attitude will always be helpful. But you gotta find out whether you are giving up on your goal or on the paths you are trying ? I read many answers of this thread, many agreed on it and some didn’t but the essence was missing here which made me write this answer. Rana Ashish (who is also one of my favorite writer) also wrote a story about an ant. Rana Ashish's answer to Is the "never give up" attitude always helpful? He denied in his answer and said this attitude does not help every time (which many people misunderstood). But we need to remember that, the goal of an ant is to go beyond the wall. Ant may give up on her paths but must not give up on her Goal. If you will give up on the endeavors you are doing and try a different one that will be fine. But if you will give up on your goal then I am pretty sure, It won’t make any sense ! If you can’t fly, then run. If you can’t run then walk. If you can’t walk, then crawl. But whatever you do, you have to keep moving forward. -Martin Luther King Jr.

Sure, it works. It just works in that one's stick-to-itiveness is hands down better than a pessimistic attitude. I have a past student who comes to mind. I was her high school math teacher. She is NOT a math talent, but she would just NOT give up. She sends me messages from time to time about her successes in college math. My mother used to say to me about my being a stubborn boy, "Ray, you will see as you get older that your stubbornness is not just a problem: it will become one of your strengths." My mother was a wise woman.  Now, that being said, we still need to learn from our failed attempts. Trying EXACTLY the same thing is probably not a good idea. Never giving up does NOT mean not learning from our failed attempts. It means just the opposite.  When, also, you put an indomitable will to doing something, you will blow YOURSELF away with the results. My own life's best example of this is when I got disgusted with how dirty my high school of 2500 students was. I devised a plan, worked all Spring Break, including with other teachers and students, and - believe it or not - in three days our school went from the dirtiest high school campus you can imagine to the cleanest one you would ever see. It helps when you want something, it is right, and you don't even think of failing. That program (in which I once a weak dressed up as Mr. Clean with earring and clean-shaven head) lasted for a couple of months and changed the culture of the school. My point - hopefully not just to brag - is that our will and perseverance is not just a successful strategy, but, maybe, essential. Cheers,   ray

Giving up too soon is a problem and not knowing when to quit is a stressful and draining problem. Many moons ago, when I and my friends enrolled for graduation, a friend of ours enrolled for a popular Indian accountancy certification exam. This exam has three levels and with each level the difficulty level increases, and to maintain the supply and demand of such accountants the pass percentage is usually really low. So, many people at times give 2-3 attempts or even more to clear a single level. Usually, this qualification is associated with a high aspirational value, really smart people do, a high pay job and a lot of respect. And so it goes, my friend who enrolled for this certification, who was also a brilliant student, enrolled for this exam. While we graduated, she was still trying to clear the level I one of this exam. Even though she was a smart student, somehow, she couldn’t clear the exams in a single attempt, it was really frustrating for her, more so because it was for her family. The more the frustration grew the less she scored, and the longer time it took her to pass. In many years, while most of us completed double degrees, took a job, changed jobs, got promotions, got married and some got kids too, she struggled to clear the exams, she went into depression, came out somehow, again attempted exams, and attempted… I even lost tracks how many times she attempted for the levels in totality, last I heard from her was, "Yeah, I am a housewife now, with no purpose of life." She was once upon a time a brilliant student, but because she didn't know when to quit, she kept trying for something which was never meant for her. She kept judging and punishing herself for something which, I believe, was not even the best parameter to judge her smartness. Maybe that exam demanded some other kind of proficiency, something which she doesn’t have, but she had many other wonderful skills using which she could have excelled in life. More often than not, most of us miss judge, never give up attitude with never quit anything else you will be labeled as a loser attitude- and this attitude has ruined many lives. We often fail to quit that relationship which is no longer going anywhere, that exam which has eaten our endless years, that business which was a dream once but is not working anymore, that job which is stopping our growth. Quitting or giving up is a temporary set back that can be overcome by putting energy and efforts at the right place, in the right direction, and that sort of never give up attitude is always helpful.

These 10 Stories Will Remind You To Never Give Up On Your Dreams  Every now and again, I go through times where I feel like it’s all too hard; that it would be easier to just throw in the towel. Perhaps you feel the same at times, too. In these scenarios, I like to remind myself of just how far people have come to reach success. I get inspired by reading stories of entrepreneurs, inventors and leaders and how they overcame many failures and rejections, so I’ve put together 10 famous personalities who truly inspire me and I’m sure they will inspire you too — no matter your journey. Mind you, these people weren’t born with a silver spoon in their mouth (except for Franklin Roosevelt). Here are the 10 personalities who have overcome the odds: 1) Thomas Edison  First on the list is Thomas Edison. Have you ever felt discouraged just because you failed, maybe once or twice? Did your teacher called you stupid just because you can’t answer a simple math problem? Got fired from your job? Well, you’re not alone! Sir Thomas Edison isn’t as intelligent as you thought he was. In fact, during his early days, even his teachers told him that he’s “too dumb to learn anything and there’s no hope for him.” He even stopped his formal education at the age of 12. Not only that, he also failed more or less a thousand times with his inventions. Likewise, he even got fired from his first two jobs — after leaking acid on to his boss’ desk, but he didn’t give up and he didn’t let those failures drag him down. Instead, he ignored those criticisms and despite being almost penniless, he turned out to be the most successful inventor of his generation. Having a great influence from motion picture cameras to creating the light bulb. Come to think of it, if he did give up, you’ll probably be using candles up to now. One of his famous quotes is, “Every wrong attempt discarded, is another step forward.” 2) Harland David Sanders (Colonel Sanders )  If you’re one of those people who uses the excuse, “I’m too old, there’s no way I can be successful anymore.” Think again. It’s never too late for success. A great example of this would be, Colonel Sanders. If you’re not familiar who this guy is, he’s just the founder of the ever famous Kentucky Fried Chicken (KFC). One of the biggest fast food corporations worldwide. Though, it wasn’t an instant success. Colonel Harland Sanders started his dream at 65 years old. For most, this would be the time to retire and enjoy the remaining years of their lives. However, Colonel Sanders turned this the other way around. After getting his retirement benefits, he used his first social security check, amounting to one hundred and five dollars, to start a business (once again) — the start of his journey. Most people would complain after receiving this amount. Not him, though. He believed that restaurant owners would love his original fried chicken recipe and he’d get a small percentage once the sales increase. It wasn’t an easy job. He drove around Kentucky, knocking on every door, sleeping inside his car, and to look formal, he always wore his signature white suit. Even though KFC is very famous now, do you know how many times people ignored his offer and said, “NO?” Only 1,009 times, but that didn’t stop him until he got a “Yes!” 3) Steve Jobs  Say, are you a college dropout? Steve Jobs, the founder of Apple didn’t get his college diploma either, but this didn’t stop him from dreaming big. He even took his greatest failures and transformed them into his greatest success. At a young age of 19, Steve Jobs, together with his friend Dan Kottke decided to drop out of Reed College and moved to India instead. What’s their reason? To find Philosophical Enlightenment. A stage of Jobs’ life where he learned the power of intuition– something that greatly influenced his works. He was a visionary perfectionist that most people think highly of him during his early years. However, at the age of 30, his own company (Apple Inc.) decided to fire him. Can you imagine the company you’ve built from scratch, turning his back against you, leaving you humiliated, depressed, and most importantly, unemployed? Well, Steve Jobs tried to overcome that and he succeeded. 11 years after Apple decided to fire him, the company was on the verge of bankruptcy. A time where Microsoft was soaring high. Being the brain behind Apple Inc., the company was desperate and crawled back to Steve Jobs — asking if he could consider coming back. Basically, he took this offer and made Apple one of the most leading pioneers when it comes to new gadgets and technologies. 4) Albert Einstein  Laziness is not an indication that you’re not a genius, or you’ll never become successful. Just look at Einstein! Even though he’s considered as an epitome of genius back then, he was the exact opposite. His communication skills didn’t even develop until he was four. His parents even thought that something was awfully wrong with him. Likewise, from elementary to college, his teachers and professors labeled him as insubordinate, sloppy, and lazy. They believed that he’ll never become successful. However, what appeared to be laziness in school, was just really boredom. He’s not the type who’d memorize the facts written in the book. Rather, he preferred to analyze things, such as: why is the sky blue? Why does the needle of a compass point in a single way? Unfortunately, these weren’t taught in school. So, how did he become a genius? Well, he didn’t let his failures, shortcomings, or flaws overshadow his potentials. At the age of 11, he became friends with Max Talmud. A 21 year old medical student who introduced Einstein to several books about science and philosophy. Einstein flourished in this learning environment, and before Max knew it, Einstein has already surpassed what he could teach the young Einstein. 5) Abraham Lincoln  Don’t let your failures bring you down. Don’t be a quitter, persistence is the key! And that’s what Lincoln did. If you’re not aware, this great man encountered a lot of failures. Failure after failure. In fact, it even seemed like it was endless! He could’ve quit many times, but he chose not to. The result, he became one of the greatest presidents of all time. Though, before becoming a president, he encountered several failures. Some of these are: his mother died; his business failed; he tried to run for state legislature and he lost; he got fired from his job; he wanted to go to law school, but he couldn’t even get in; he tried starting a business and borrowed some money from his friends but at the end of the year, he faced bankruptcy. Can you imagine how tough it was for him? Though, he never gave up. Around 1834, he tried running for state legislature again and he won this time. Likewise, a year after, he got engaged and was about to be married. Unfortunately, it seemed like lady luck fell asleep once again. His sweetheart died and Abe had a total nervous breakdown and was bedridden for six months. After that, he tried entering politics and faced defeat for a number of times. Still, it didn’t make him lose hope, and in 1860 he was elected president of the US. Thus, his legacy lives on– a man who changed a nation despite many adversities and failures. 6) Oprah Winfrey  Your failures should be your stepping stone to greatness. It doesn’t matter if you’re poor, your parents are irresponsible, you’ve been sexually abused, or people judged you because of your skin color. Don’t let these things bring you down. Even the most powerful entrepreneurs faced the same dilemma, and Oprah Winfrey is a living example. The first African-American billionaire. Most of us had a wonderful childhood; but not Oprah. When she was 9, she’d been sexually abused by her cousins and even the friends of her mom. At the age of 14, she got pregnant and her son died during infancy. However, she developed an oracle gift in church, and in 1971, she entered Tennessee State University. Landing her first job in radio and television broadcasting. She got her first position as an evening news anchor for Baltimore WJZ-TV, but got fired shortly. Not because she doesn’t have the talent, but because she’s “unfit” for TV. For her, this experience was humiliating and embarrassing. She even got sexually harassed. Although, she didn’t allow these obstacles, trials, and challenges to defeat her. She converted these misfortunes into great success. Oprah became a talk show host for AM Chicago, and she managed to make the ratings sky rocket in just a month; and in 1986, The Oprah Winfrey Show came to life. Back then, most talk show hosts concentrate on trashy topics. On the other hand, Oprah focused on the middle class, and self-help topics. Her witty humor and warm welcome made her gain the sympathy of the crowd. Her talent as a talk show host, combined with her entrepreneurial skills brought her a net worth of more or less 2.9 billion dollars. 7) Henry Ford  Failure isn’t that bad. In fact, you could even learn from it. Therefore, it is something that we should embrace. Even Henry Ford failed- he failed a lot, but he utilized what he learned from these failures and built a successful company that’s still going strong even today. This man viewed failure as an opportunity to begin (and try) again, only more intelligently this time. He even managed to overcome significant setbacks before arriving at the winning formula that made him reign in the automobile industry today. He faced bankruptcy before launching Ford Motor Company. Likewise, he faced several failures before his first Model T was ever made. Despite failing as a business man, he was determined to become successful. With that, through persistence and determination, he became one of the richest entrepreneurs globally. 8) J.K. Rowling  Do you know anyone who’s richer than the Queen of England? It’s no other than J.K. Rowling, the famous author of the series, Harry Potter– having a net worth that’s over $1 billion. No, she wasn’t born with a silver spoon in her mouth. She’s no better than you during her early years. In fact, there was a time that she lived in an Edinburgh apartment that was greatly infested with rats! She’s a single mother who struggled just to make ends meet. Basically, you could say that her life was very miserable. Being unemployed, she even had to juggle between a baby and her typewriter when she was writing her first book. Moreover, she didn’t even have the privilege to do this in the comforts of her home, but in a cafe. Even the series that we love today? The first book, Harry Potter and the Philosopher’s Stone faced twelve rejections before it managed to become a successful hit. However, her determination took her from rags to riches. She’s a great example that anyone could attain great success even against all odds. 9) Franklin Roosevelt  Are you afraid of committing failures? Why? Just because you think it’s impossible, it doesn’t imply that it really is. In fact, you’ll never know until you try. That’s what Franklin Roosevelt believed in. Before becoming the 32nd president of the United States, Teddy Roosevelt faced many hardships in life. Despite the fact that he was born into a life of wealth and extreme privilege, that didn’t make things easier for him. Yes, he managed to graduate in a prestigious school and entered a life of politics in 1910. However, during the fateful year of 1921, he was infected with polio. His body was nearly paralyzed and he lost his legs during the battle. With this, he went through a period of extreme depression, but he knew that he shouldn’t give up. In 1928, even being confined in a wheelchair he still tried to re-enter politics and became the president of the United States for 4 terms. Franklin Roosevelt experienced a spiritual healing during the years of his illness. Before, he used to be arrogant and insensitive. However, after that incident, he became a warmhearted person with a deeper philosophy in life. Instead of letting his impairment make him appear weak, he emerged as a better person. 10) Walt Disney  You can’t deny the fact that sometimes, it feels like things aren’t working out the way you want it. That the whole universe is against you. That your life is a complete mess, and your only wish is to experience more success. Walt Disney felt the same. Life wasn’t easy for him. As a matter of fact, Walt Disney experienced so many failures, but that didn’t even tempt him to give up. You think that Walt Disney has a very wild imagination? Well, he was fired as a newspaper editor before; and according to his boss, he lacked imagination and his ideas are no good. Also, he tried to start a business but faced bankruptcy before it even gained success. He was literally and figuratively broke, all he had was his dreams and aspirations. Though, he never got tired and continued to try new ideas until he reached success; and once it did, it was overwhelming. He managed to win 22 Academy Awards and established the first Disneyland in California around 1955. Today, the Walt Disney Company rakes in billions of dollars annually from movies, theme parks, and merchandise around the world. Anything Is Possible I hope that these famous personalities inspired you to strive harder and aim higher. Despite several failures and circumstances, it doesn’t mean that success would be out of reach. Hence, with deliberate determination, anything is possible. Tell me, what do you want in life? Perhaps, for now, it seems virtually impossible to attain that goal, but keep in mind that you’re not alone. Most successful individuals faced the same struggles before they reached the peak of success. We all know that overcoming failures is not a piece of cake. Though these 10 personalities faced an impossible battle and they conquered. So think again!  This article originally appeared on Medium

This is a true story of a young woman who went through the most gruesome fire. When you read her story, you’ll realize that your trials are absolutely nothing compared to what this young girl went through. It was September 25, 2000. Maricel Apatan was an 11-year old girl in Zamboanga. On that day, this little girl went with her uncle to draw water. Along the way, four men met them. They were carrying long knives. They told her uncle to face down on the ground, and they hacked him on the neck and killed him. Maricel was in total shock, especially that the men were their neighbors. She tried to escape, but the men ran after her. She cried, “Kuya, ‘wag po, ‘wag n’yo akong tagain! Maawa po kayo sa akin!” (“Don’t kill me! Have mercy on me!”) But they weren’t listening. With a long knife, a man slashed her on the neck too. Maricel fell to the ground and lost consciousness. When she woke up, she saw a lot of blood. She also saw the feet of the men around her, but she pretended to be dead. When they walked away, Maricel ran back home. But along the way, she saw that both her hands were falling off. Because the men hacked them too. She cried but she kept running. Sometimes, she would faint and fall to the ground. But she’d regain consciousness and run again. When she was near her home, Maricel called her mother. Upon seeing her daughter, her mother screamed in terror. She wrapped her bloodied child in a blanket and carried her to the hospital. Here was the problem: From her house to the highway, it was a 12-kilometer walk. It took them 4 hours just to reach the highway. When they arrived in the hospital, the doctors thought Maricel was going to die. But for 5 hours, they operated on her. It took 25 stitches to stitch together the long knife wound in her neck and back. Maricel barely survived. And she lost both of her hands. Ironically, the next day was Maricel’s birthday. She was 12 years old. But tragedy didn’t end there. When they went home, they saw their home was gone. It was ransacked and burned down by the goons. Being very poor, Maricel’s family also didn’t have P50,000 for their hospital bills. But God sent many angels along the way to help them. Archbishop Antonio Ledesma, a distant relative, paid for hospital bills and helped them bring the criminals to court. They were sentenced to prison. Today, she’s staying with the nuns at Regina Rosarii with Sr. Eppie Brasil, O.P. But this is the incredible miracle. Instead of staying down, Maricel kept running. Instead of cursing God why she had no hands, she now uses her wrists in incredible ways that will boggle your mind.  Maricel Apatan Maricel was cited as the most industrious, best in computer, and most courteous in the School for Crippled Children. In 2008, she graduated from a course in Hotel and Restaurant Management. She even received a Gold medal for Arts and Crafts. In 2011, she finished her education to be a chef. Yes, a Chef without hands. Nothing can stop this young lady from reaching her dreams. Real Winners Don’t Give Up!

Great things take time Is this always true ? I am still thinking. I read the above quote whenever I stand in the line in the mess hall of my hostel waiting for hot food and said to myself “Yes! Great food takes time”. Before reaching any conclusions, what qualifies to be called as ‘Great thing’ and what does ‘time’ imply here. In literal sense Great does mean- above average, important & beautiful.Great things vary according to the perception.What may appear great to you, may not appear to someone else. To my father , being school 4th seemed great. Now, I believe it doesn't anymore. What is great changes with time too. But let’s consider ‘Great as something synonymous with ‘getting out of poverty’, ‘ flying to the moon’, ‘Being Famous’, ‘Richest cream’, ‘Becoming powerful’, ‘Staying powerful’, ‘being happy’ or simply ‘being employed in a stable and secure job’. But remember, all success is not great. And time here is inevitably long-term. How long is ‘long-term’? For the above mentioned great things , I assume that it takes anything more than at least 5 years. Although being happy might seem to be an exception.Yet in most cases, society wont let you be happy until you seem great. It’s for you to decide to be happy or be great or both. Time is to be viewed as multidimensional here and let us assume it is a function of space, circumstances and work done exclusively to that particular “great thing”. The GREAT wall of China took an incredible 2000 years.Did Thomas Alva Edison have to fail 10,000 times ?World Economic Forum finds that it takes 99.5 years to close the Gender gap to zero, but the image looks hazy even after that, if pandemics and other disasters continue to take place. What it takes to become the first Black President of the country ? For Nelson Mandela to spend a gratifyingly long 27 years in South African prisons. Elon musk, founder of SpaceX says that people need to work from around 80 to over 100 hours per week to change the world. How many hours do you work ? When I was discussing the same with my friend, he asked to think about the unsuccessful people. I pondered for a while and it occurred to me that , People who stop trying, are failures. Oprah Winfrey, a billionaire with her own TV channel was once a failure. She was fired from her stint as aTV anchor. And she reflected “There is no such thing as failure. Failure is just life trying to move us in another direction.” Others who travelled the journey of consecutive failures before becoming GREAT are J K Rowling, Katy Perry, Steven Spielberg, Nawazuddin Siddiqui, Dhirubhai Ambani ( he was not from an affluent background),Mallesham were once FAILURES. In my opinion, GREAT things take time. How much time depends on its function I stated above( space, circumstances and work done). Time is nothing but an investment. The more time one invests, the more one reaps out of it. The time one thinks of giving up is the time invested in Failure.One cannot invest time in X and earn benefits from Y. Even if one invests the entire time in X, one cannot entirely gain from X unless one meets the criteria of the skills needed to gain the fullest possible benefits. In order to be GREAT, one must outbound the set criteria. The reason you find very few GREAT women is because a notable amount of majority are obliged to the social conditioning of investing their time in the domestic chores or for making their husbands, brothers, sisters, sons, and daughters GREAT. It’s high time to invest time in making yourselves and the WORLD a GREAT place. Is being great enough ?  Never ever give up !!

Case I: An almost 2½ year relationship. Lots of incidents during its course that pointed towards things not working out in the long run. Lies, arguments, negativity, too much emotional attachment, etc. All in all, we weren't that compatible as we thought we'd be. But me being me, I kept on trying and trying to fix things up somehow. Well, he tried too. But boy, did it go downhill despite all the efforts put in. I guess that's what happens when a person doesn't really have the will to be with you, when they have some serious things of their own to sort out.  Where did it get me?To the lowest point I've ever been in 20 years of my life, emotionally, physically, as well as mentally. What did I learn?Among other things, learn to let go before it gets too late.You cannot help someone who doesn't want to be helped.   Case II: A friendship of 3 years and still going good. Started out real good, we clicked instantly. Great emotional connection, all the care and love two friends can have.Few things go wrong (afore mentioned relationship included), some pretty stupid but significant mistakes get committed, hurtful words are said. Communication reduces to almost none.Miscommunications and misunderstandings that we didn't even imagine could happen.And all this happened when we both needed real good focus in our lives, needed support. Somehow, we talk and discuss things. None of us are the 'give up easily' kind. Few things get cleared up. Others seem too much to forget, or at least have that kinda trust again. But we both hung on by the littlest of threads because we could clearly see that we both didn't want things to end.Owned up to our faults, worked on making things better. Things went bad again, what with all the vulnerability and fear of getting hurt. Again we talked and decided to give it another try.Short period of peace, something came up yet again. Knowing each other too well can go wrong at times. But before it became too much, we sorted it out.Took great effort, always will. That's what it takes to maintain a healthy relation. Where am I now?Friends with one of the most awesome guys in the world.Yea, we still got few issues to work on, but we're back on track. What did I learn?Unconditional relations are really worth never giving up on.   So, there you go. Is 'never giving up' always helpful?Nope. You'll have to fight your battles as they come along. You cannot fix your approach for every situation.You see danger, you back off.You see potential, you hold on real tight. Of course that's the trick.To know when to give up and when not to. Good luck!(:

I will say something controversial here, please hear me out. This attitude is not always helpful. Society always ask us to strive for the best and never give up, yes I agree with this to a certain extant. But, what if you have tried your best but you don’t succeed?  Say for example you enter a competition, its your first time and you didn’t win. It’s okay, you are inexperienced and this is normal. Perhaps you can try harder to win the next time. Now it’s your second year, you enter the same competition. You tried your very best again. Somehow for whatever reason, you lost again. It’s alright, maybe someone else tried harder than you and you should be more well prepared. Finally, the third time arrives. You have prepared yourself sufficiently throughout the year, you tried to think of how you can win ethically from every angle, you are filled with confidence that finally you can have a breakthrough and nail it this year. You lost again. Your friends look down upon you, people berate you, others shake their heads in disappointment. Right now you feel dejected. Why can’t I win? I have tried my very best, yet the outcome is not changing? Have I not done all that I could, why then am I still stuck here?  Consider the scenario above. You didn’t give up previously, you prepared to the best that you can, but the outcome is not changing. Not giving up is good if you have not tried to the best of your abilities; but when you already have and still fail, perhaps it is better to give up instead. There maybe various reasons why you gave up, perhaps what you invest in becomes more of a burden than an enjoyment, perhaps it is harming you or those around you, perhaps it is just not your forte, or perhaps it is consuming too much of you but is still not producing any positive results. For example, I can force you to be a mathematician, but if your real strength lies in music, it will be a waste of talent. Likewise, if you are a methodical and are passionate for numbers, asking you to be something else which robs you of opportunities will not fare well for you. Hence, it is better to give up only when you have tried all that you can, yet can’t progress any further.  I am not saying that when things are tough you should give up immediately. Rather when your heart of hearts knows that you can’t move onward in that field, then you can consider stopping and being content. Giving up is not the first option, it is the last option. However at the same time, you should know and identify where your real passions and strengths lie, then progress in that direction. Knowing when to give up and when to not give up is important, but when you do find yourself in a situation where you need to give up, learn to be content with your decision. Do not feel bitter at yourself just because things aren’t working out, just because you can’t succeed now means it is definitely your fault. Maybe this area is not where you ought to be, but someday you will definitely find somewhere you will belong to.

A very dear friend was a hardcore Transport Pilot optee. While most of the Air Force cadets dreamt of flying the Migs and the Sukhoi, he was a laidback character who wanted to enjoy flying the Antonovs and the Dorniers. Fortunately, or unfortunately after passing out of the National Defene Academy, his instructor at the Air Force Academy was a hardcore fighter pilot. He had a very strong reputation in the cockpit and often his pupils came out with broken helmets, masks and visors. My friend was terrified of him and still hates him. He wanted to give up flying because he was afraid of sitting with his instructor in the cockpit. Many times, he decided that he will apply for a change of branch to administration or logistics but he didn’t because being a pilot was what we all had dreamt of from the first day in National Defence Academy. With a bruised eye, and a bleeding nose, he cleared his solo. He was thankful he didn’t give up then but what he didn’t realise was that it was the fear of his instructor that made him prepare better and perform better than others. He passed out as one of the best flyers in merit. The nail in the coffin however was that he was alloted fighter stream despite being a transport optee. He felt really down that day, but he thought at least I’ll be flying and went ahead. He wanted to go to the Mig 29 squadron but after training on the Hawks for a year, he was sent to a Mig 21 Squadron. He was really frustrated by now as fighter flying sucks up your mental and physical energy initially. He was a junior pilot in a Mig 21 Squadron and used to wait on the ORP for hours daily to scramble. He was doing all this despite still having a liking for transport stream. Last year, his aircraft was changed. He finally got the Mig 29. He was happy as hell. He got married as well, bought a dog and now leads a content life which he might not have if he had applied for change of branch because of his instructor or when he was allotted fighter stream or when he was given the Mig 21. Be logical even when you decide not to give up. Weigh the pros and cons and most importantly, don’t let emotions get the better of you. Sometimes we don’t realise what we have and run behind things which are out of reach for a reason. We all can fly, only if we think we can and if we dont give up.

Well, it really depends on the people and their circumstances. This strategy really made sense in many instances. Abraham Lincoln became president of the United States because he never gave up.Thomas Alva Edison invented first light bulb after 10000 failures. And he said he found 10,000 different ways that did not work! Look at his attitude towards failure! There's lot to learn!Even the world famous rapper Eminem has the same attitude! That's the reason he is now the 'Rap God'.Michael Jordan, Walt Disney, Steve Jobs, Albert Einstein and if we go on, the list will have no end. And remember that we only talked about famous people who failed and didn't choose failure as an option. If we just look around, we will get to know about many common people who thought success is the only option they have.And at the same time there are other situations where this won't work at all. For example if you are in an abusive relationship and waiting for your partner to change, that's foolish.And if you are wasting time on someone expecting them to realize your importance..this will never work! Finally, it's you who have to decide when to apply the strategy and when to not!
